searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: QuickBounds is at its core a module that lets you track parts that enter user-defined static zones. It uses a Bounding Volume Hierarchy under the hood to make sure the module doesn't eat up much frame time even with a large number of zones or tracked parts.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: For both pesde and wally, the package name + version is  unityjaeger/quickbounds@0.3.4   Or if you want the source, then just grab it from the latest release from the Releases tab.

searchDocs.title: Quick Start​
searchDocs.content: --create a group (optionally with a priority) local group = QuickBounds.createGroup(10) --lower priority groups get prioritized --add a basepart to the group to be tracked (optionally with custom data) group:add(workspace.ExamplePart, "custom data") --create a zone local zone = QuickBounds.createZoneFromInstance(workspace.ExampleZonePart) --make the zone start watching the example group zone:watchGroups(group) --register callbacks for zone entering/exiting group:onEntered(function(part, zone, customData) --if the zone was registered with createZoneFromInstance then zone.part will be the Instance passed to that function, otherwise it will be nil print(part, "entered", zone.part, "with custom data", customData) end) group:onExited(function(part, zone, customData) --if the zone was registered with createZoneFromInstance then zone.part will be the Instance passed to that function, otherwise it will be nil print(part, "exited", zone.part, "with custom data", customData) end)

searchDocs.title: UID​
searchDocs.content: </> Group.UID: number Unique identifier for this group.

searchDocs.title: add​
searchDocs.content: </> Group:add( part: BasePart , customData: any? ) → () Start tracking the specified BasePart.

searchDocs.title: remove​
searchDocs.content: </> Group:remove(part: BasePart ) → () Makes the group stop tracking the specified BasePart.

searchDocs.title: setPriority​
searchDocs.content: </> Group:setPriority(priority: number) → () Groups with the same priority can be entered by a BasePart that is a member of both groups simultaneously. If the groups have a different priority then the one with a lower priority will win.

searchDocs.title: onEntered​
searchDocs.content: </> Group:onEntered(callback: ( part: BasePart , zone: Zone, customData: any? ) → ()) → () → () Tracks whenever a BasePart that is a member of this group enters this group through a Zone with the use of a callback function, returns a cleanup function.

searchDocs.title: onExited​
searchDocs.content: </> Group:onExited(callback: ( part: BasePart , zone: Zone, customData: any? ) → ()) → () → () Tracks whenever a BasePart that is a member of this group exits this group through a Zone with the use of a callback function, returns a cleanup function.

searchDocs.title: part​
searchDocs.content: </> Zone.part: BaseClass? If available, the BasePart associated with the zone object.

searchDocs.title: index​
searchDocs.content: </> Zone.index: number Used for internal data structures.

searchDocs.title: watchGroups​
searchDocs.content: </> Zone:watchGroups(...: ...Group) → () Start watching the specified groups.

searchDocs.title: unwatchGroups​
searchDocs.content: </> Zone:unwatchGroups(...: ...Group) → () Stop watching the specified groups.

searchDocs.title: destroy​
searchDocs.content: </> Zone:destroy() → ()

searchDocs.title: Player Addon​
searchDocs.content: This addon abstracts management of the player character away so that it's more comfortable to work with players.  It exposes a function to add players to groups and a function to remove players from groups.  Basic usage looks like this:  local exampleGroup = QuickBounds.createGroup() local zone = QuickBounds.createZoneFromInstance(workspace.ExampleZone) zone:watchGroups(exampleGroup) game.Players.PlayerAdded:Connect(function(player) PlayerAddon.addPlayerToGroups(player, exampleGroup) end) exampleGroup:onEntered(function(rootPart, zone, player) print(player.Name, "entered zone", zone.part) end) exampleGroup:onExited(function(rootPart, zone, player) print(player.Name, "exited zone", zone.part) end)   Cleanup when players leave is done automatically, so you don't need to manually remove the player from all groups when the player leaves.  If you want to use this addon with StreamingEnabled on the Client then you have to set the player characters to Persistent on the server.

searchDocs.title: createZone​
searchDocs.content: </> QuickBounds.createZone( cframe: CFrame , size: Size, shape: "Block" | "Ball" | "Cylinder" | "Wedge" ) → Zone

searchDocs.title: createZoneFromInstance​
searchDocs.content: </> QuickBounds.createZoneFromInstance(part: BasePart ) → Zone Creates and returns a Zone built from an instance, does not support Corner Wedges.

searchDocs.title: setFrameBudget​
searchDocs.content: </> QuickBounds.setFrameBudget(budget: number) → () Sets the frame budget available for each processing frame, in seconds.

searchDocs.title: createGroup​
searchDocs.content: </> QuickBounds.createGroup(priority: number?) → Group Creates and returns a group, with an optionally specified priority. Default priority is 1e6 (100'000).

searchDocs.title: isPartInGroup​
searchDocs.content: </> QuickBounds.isPartInGroup( part: BasePart , group: Group ) → boolean Checks if the BasePart is member of the group, not if it's currently physically inside of the group.

searchDocs.title: getPartsForGroup​
searchDocs.content: </> QuickBounds.getPartsForGroup(group: Group) → {BasePart } Returns all parts that are a member of the group.

searchDocs.title: getGroupsForPart​
searchDocs.content: </> QuickBounds.getGroupsForPart(part: BasePart ) → {Group} Returns all groups that the BasePart is a member of.

searchDocs.title: Zones​
searchDocs.content: Zones are static areas in your map, either defined by a part  QuickBounds.createZoneFromInstance(workspace.ZonePart)   or with a cframe, size and shape.  QuickBounds.createZone( CFrame.new(0, 5, 0), Vector3.new(10, 10, 10), "Box" )   You can also destroy zones by simply calling destroy on them.  local zone = QuickBounds.createZone( CFrame.new(0, 5, 0), Vector3.new(10, 10, 10), "Box" ) zone:Destroy()

searchDocs.title: Groups​
searchDocs.content: Groups are collections of zones, where a zone can be a member of any number of groups.

searchDocs.title: Creation​
searchDocs.content: local group = QuickBounds.createGroup(10) --you can also assign a different priority later group:setPriority(5)   The number you pass into createGroup is that group's priority, lower priorities will win over higher priorities and the default priority when no number is passed is 100000.

searchDocs.title: Adding and Removing Parts​
searchDocs.content: local group = QuickBounds.createGroup(10) group:add(workspace.ExamplePart, {belongsTo = players.xyz})   To start tracking parts, you need to call group:add like above for any part you want the group to track. The second argument is your custom data, it can be whatever you want and is also unique to whatever group you add the part to. You can also naturally add a part to any number of groups.  For a practical example you can take a look at the Player Addon  To remove a part from a group simply call  local group = QuickBounds.createGroup(10) group:remove(workspace.ExamplePart)

searchDocs.title: Zones and Groups​
searchDocs.content: local group = QuickBounds.createGroup(10) local otherGroup = QuickBounds.createGroup(5) local zone = QuickBounds.createZoneFromInstance(workspace.ZonePart) zone:watchGroups(group, otherGroup)   To make zones part of a group, you call watchGroups like above on a zone.  To remove zones from a group, you call unwatchGroups in the same way:  local group = QuickBounds.createGroup(10) local otherGroup = QuickBounds.createGroup(5) local zone = QuickBounds.createZoneFromInstance(workspace.ZonePart) zone:watchGroups(group, otherGroup) zone:unwatchGroups(otherGroup)

searchDocs.title: Tracking Parts​
searchDocs.content: Instead of tracking parts per zone, parts are tracked per group, meaning if a part enters any zone that is a member of a group, the group will be notified.  local group = QuickBounds.createGroup() group:onEntered(function(part: BasePart, zone: QuickBounds.Zone, customData: any?) print(part, "entered this group") end) group:onExited(function(part: BasePart, zone: QuickBounds.Zone, customData: any?) print(part, "exited this group") end)   You can also register as many callbacks as you like.  The first parameter passed to the callback function is the part that entered the group, the second parameter is the zone object as returned by createZone or createZoneFromInstance, where a zone.part field will exist if the zone was created with createZoneFromInstance. The third parameter is the custom data that was registered when adding the part to this group.  Both onEntered and onExited return a cleanup function that will deregister the callback.

searchDocs.title: Frame Budget​
searchDocs.content: The module lets you define a custom frame budget in seconds, everything that the library does per frame and everything your callbacks do will count towards the remaining frame budget, the default frame budget is 1ms.  QuickBounds.setFrameBudget(2/1000) --2ms

searchDocs.title: Helper Functions​
searchDocs.content: isPartInGroup - quickly check if a part is currently inside of a group  local group = QuickBounds.createGroup() print(QuickBounds.isPartInGroup(workspace.ExamplePart, group))   getGroupsForPart - get all groups that a part is currently inside of  for _, group in QuickBounds.getGroupsForPart(workspace.ExamplePart) do print(group) end   getPartsForGroup - get all parts that are currently inside of the specified group  local group = QuickBounds.createGroup() for _, part in QuickBounds.getPartsForGroup(group) do print(part) end

searchDocs.title: Considerations​
searchDocs.content: only the center of parts are tracked and their size is not included for calculations, this is important to keep in mind when you have small/flat zones or big partsparts are not guaranteed to touch a zone if they skip over the zone between 2 processing frames
